    Modifying configuration settings

    On This Page

    • Configurations to set
    • Setting during installation
    • Modifying post-installation

    You can use a ConfigMap to install IBM Event Streams with a custom set of Kafka configurations.

    You can use the IBM Event Streams CLI to modify the brokers and cluster-wide configuration for your IBM Event Streams instance dynamically.

    You can also use the IBM Event Streams CLI to modify read-only configuration settings.

    Configurations to set

    For a list of all configuration settings you can specify for Kafka brokers, see the Kafka documentation.

    Some of the broker configuration settings can be updated without restarting the broker, while others require a restart:

    • read-only: Requires a broker restart for the update to take effect.
    • per-broker: Can be updated dynamically for each broker without a broker restart.
    • cluster-wide: Can be updated dynamically as a cluster-wide default, or as a per-broker value for testing purposes.

    See the Dynamic Update Mode column in the Kafka documentation for the update mode of each broker configuration.

    Note: You cannot modfiy the following properties.

    • broker.id
    • listeners
    • zookeeper.connect
    • advertised.listeners
    • inter.broker.listener.name
    • listener.security.protocol.map
    • authorizer.class.name
    • principal.builder.class
    • sasl.enabled.mechanisms
    • log.dirs

    Setting during installation

    To specify broker configuration settings when installing IBM Event Streams, create a ConfigMap to use with the installation and provide the ConfigMap name to the installation process.

    1. Using the IBM Cloud Private CLI, log in to your cluster as an administrator:
      cloudctl login -a https://<master-ip>:8443 -u <username> -p <password>
    2. To create a ConfigMap by using an existing Kafka server.properties file, use the following command:
      kubectl -n <namespace_name> create configmap <configmap_name> --from-env-file=<full_path/server.properties>
      You can also create a blank ConfigMap for future configuration updates by using the following command:
      kubectl -n <namespace_name> create configmap <configmap_name>
    3. When installing IBM Event Streams, ensure you provide the name of the ConfigMap you created in the ConfigMap Name field of the Kafka broker configuration section when specifying the configuration settings for the deployment. In addition, the ConfigMap must be in the same namespace as where you intend to install the IBM Event Streams release.

    Modifying post-installation

    You can modify per-broker and cluster-wide configuration settings dynamically (without a broker restart) by using the IBM Event Streams CLI:

    1. Using the IBM Cloud Private CLI, log in to your cluster as an administrator:
      cloudctl login -a https://<master-ip>:8443 -u <username> -p <password>
    2. Run the following command to start the IBM Event Streams CLI: cloudctl es init

    You can also update your read-only configuration settings that require a broker restart by using the IBM Event Streams CLI.

    Note: Read-only settings require a ConfigMap to be set. If you did not create and specify a ConfigMap during the installation process, you can create a ConfigMap later with the required Kafka configuration settings or create a blank one as described earlier. You can then make the ConfigMap available to your IBM Event Streams instance:

    helm upgrade --reuse-values --set kafka.configMapName=<configmap_name> <release_name> <full_path>/ibm-eventstreams-prod

    The ConfigMap is required to apply changes to the read-only Kafka configurations stored in the server.properties when you use a command similar to the following:

    cloudctl es cluster-config --config max.message.bytes=2048 --read-only
